div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.p: Jasmine is a behavior-driven development framework. If you want to test UI with Rapise in a behavior-driven way learn how to tie Rapise and Jasmine together.

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: How to fix IE 11 recording/playback on Windows 64-bit

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.p: Symptoms:

ol.li: When new recording is started Rapise always opens new IE window
Spy does not show DOM tree
During playback no object is found

h5.a: Debugging Rapise DOM libraries in Chrome using VS Code

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.p: Rapise can be extended with DOM libraries to add support for custom UI controls used in modern web applications. Many of such applications work in Chrome browser. So there may be a need to debug Rapise code embedded into Chrome via Rapise Extension for Chrome. Most powerful and easy way to do this is to add VS Code into the equation. From this article you will learn how to tie Rapise, Chrome and VS Code together.

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: Handling Auth prompt in Rapise

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.p: Some web site show Auth prompt when entering some area. The prompt is rendered differently by different browser. Here we show how to bypass the prompt in automation scripts.

h5.a: How I added support for JPopupMenu automation in 1-hour

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.p: Example of adding support for Java UI control in Rapise.

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: Using Rapise Visual Language (RVL) 5.1 with Multiple Sheets

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.p: With the release of the new Rapise Visual Language (RVL), there have been some questions about how to use it to organize tests, subtests and multiple sheets. For example:

ul.li: I see that I can create multiple sheets. How does Rapise handle multiple sheets? Does it run each in order or can they be run separately?
Is it possible to call a test in RVL from another test in RVL? In other worlds, how can I create subtests and scenarios using RVL?

h5.a: Resources for Learning JavaScript

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.p: One of the most popular programming languages in the world is JavaScript. Initially conceived by Netscape as a web page scripting language, christened JavaScript to leverage the popularity of Java (which was fairly new and sexy at the time) and now used for servers (NodeJS), desktop apps (ReactNative) and for us at Inflectra, the core technology at the heart of our Rapise test automation system. This article provides some useful resources for those first learning the language.

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: Rapise Recording/Playback Throw Error Due to ANSICON application conflict

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.p: A customer of ours was using Rapise on a computer that was also running the ANSICON application. This changed some of the settings in the Windows registry that affected the Windows command-line parser. This article explains how to clean up the command-line to allow both applications to work correctly together.

h5.a: Formatting dates in JavaScript

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.p: This is a short sample demonstrating how one can format a date

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: Changing REST Headers When Web Service Testing

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.p: When performing web service testing using Rapise you may need to change the HTTP headers being sent with the request. This article provides suggestions on the different ways of doing this.

h5.a: How to execute a JavaScript function when its name as a string

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.p: Sometimes it is convenient to store function names in strings and use those strings to call actual functions. The article describes two ways of how you can do this in Rapise.

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: Magic Tricks of the Triple Click

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: This article shows how to select paragraph of text using various types of mouse activities. Also it demonstrates use of clipboard Global.DoTrim function. Working example is attached.

h5.a: Suppressing Text in Rapise Logs for Sensitive Data

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: A customer had a question - is there a way to suppress the DoSetText or DoSendkeys methods from sending their text to the logs. They didn't want users to see this text in the Rapise (and SpiraTest) logs because they contained sensitive information (e.g. passwords).

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: Rapise Tip - How to Handle a Webpage that Displays an Alert when You Navigate Away

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: One of our users had a webpage with a form. When it was submitted partially filled, the page came back (after being processed on the backend) with some errors about incomplete form. If the user tried to navigate away from this page via a link (or close the page/browser tab) he was prompted with browser's standard "Are you sure you want to leave this page?" dialog. He needed a way for Rapise to handle this popup when recording and playing back the web test.

h5.a: Adobe Flash / Flex / AIR Support in Rapise

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div:
Rapise 4.0 supports the testing of Adobe AIR Flex applications using the Adobe Integrated Runtime (AIR). Rapise can test applications using a wide variety of different Flex controls and supports testing both Flex 3 and Flex 4 applications.
Rapise 4.0 supports the testing of Adobe Flex applications that are executed by the Adobe Flash Player inside the Internet Explorer, Mozilla Firefox or Google Chrome web browsers. Rapise can test applications using a wide variety of different Flex controls and supports testing both Flex 3 and Flex 4 applications.
[We have depreciated support for testing Adobe Flex/Flash applications in Rapise 5.0 and later, so this article is provided for use by existing customers]

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: Unusual case where Rapise Cannot Click on Hyperlinks in IE

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: We have found an occasional situation where Rapise is not able to click on hyperlinks (<A> tags) when you playback a test on IE. The same test works fine on other computers and on other browsers on the same computer.

h5.a: Web Object Not Found in IE when Object has 0px Size

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: We had a customer with a problem related to having <div> elements with complex display styles applied inside an HTML anchor tag <a>. The anchor tag was reporting back as having zero size (0px) in IE, so when Rapise tried to locate it to click on it, the browser was not able to find it.

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: Executing a Windows .BAT Batch File from Rapise

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.p: Sometimes you need to run a Windows batch file (.BAT) from Rapise. Unlike an executable, you cannot simply use Global.DoLaunch() to execute it since it's not actually an application. This article provides the code you need to use.

h5.a: Testing Popup Windows using Internet Explorer

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: When you are testing a web application that has popup windows (where the popup is a whole new browser window) you will need to make a slight change to the test script to enable it to playback successfully in Internet Explorer (no change is needed for Chrome or Firefox).

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: Troubleshooting Java Swing/AWT Testing

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: When you are testing a Java application using either Swing or AWT you may run into some issues due to the environment. This article collects some of these common cases and provides the recommended solutions.

h5.a: Where do I get the Microsoft Script Debugger

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: When you install Rapise onto a computer that does not have Visual Studio or the Microsoft Script Debugger installed you will get a message to install the debugger. This article provides the download link to the necessary debugger.

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: Testing Adobe AIR Applications on Mobile Devices

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: We have had a couple of questions about whether Rapise can test Adobe AIR based applications running on mobile devices using platforms such as Android. This article provides some background and also describes the support Rapise has.

h5.a: What to do When Rapise Doesn't Display the Web Page DOM?

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: Sometimes when testing certain web applications instead of the browser DOM tree appearing you will see strange results such as "Node0" appearing. This is caused by the application using nested frames with potentially different security origins. This article describes some of the common issues and describes the solution.

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: Rapise - Cannot Find AllLibraries.json file during Recording/Playback

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: When recording or playing back a test script on a new PC you may get an error message that Rapise cannot find the path to "AllLibraries.json".This article provides instructions on how to fix the issue.

h5.a: Testing Multiple Web Browser Tabs at Once in Chrome

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: Sometimes you have a web test where you need to test the contents of two browser tabs at the same time in Google Chrome. For example you may have an application which opens up a second browser tab and you want to test that changes in the second tab show up correctly in the first tab. This article describes how to perform this kind of testing.

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: Fixing the 'Method Not Found' error when using Appium for Mobile Testing in Rapise

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.p:
If you receive the following error message when performing Mobile device testing with Rapise, this article provides the necessary solution:
Method not found:
'OpenQA.Selenium.RemoteCommandInfoRepository
OpenQA.Selenium.RemoteCommandInfoRepository.get_Instance()'.

h5.a: Testing Web Applications that use SVG

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: One of the more challenging types of web application is that with uses embedded SVG (Scaleable Vector Graphics) in additional to HTML DOM elements. This article describes how to use Rapise to write automated testing scripts for such applications.

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: Rapise 3.x / 4.0 Does not Connect to Chrome x64 Bit

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.p: When you try and connect to the 64-bit version of the Google Chrome web browser using Rapise 4.0 (or earlier) you may get the error 'Connection to Chrome Failed!'. This issue has been fixed in the Rapise 4.1 release, but for those customers using Rapise 4.0 or earlier, this article provides two solutions.

h5.a: Working with WPF and UIAutomation Structures

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: It is a common situation that desktop applications written using Microsoft Windows Presentation Framework (WPF) will have complex layouts including tabs, splitters and panels having custom grids and tables inside. This article provides help in dealing with such situations, including how to dynamically find items.

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: Reading the Details of Files on the Windows File System

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: In the KB62 article - Accessing Files using Rapise we explain how to access the names, versions and locations of files on the Windows file system. One customer asked - can we verify any file details other than version. This article provides sample code for accessing other information.

h5.a: Accessing the Windows Registry using Rapise

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: Sometimes when testing local/desktop applications you need to access the Windows registry to verify that keys exist or that keys have specific values. For example you may be testing that a DLL was successfully registered. This article provides information on the 'UsingRegistry' sample that comes with Rapise.

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: Error attaching to Excel spreadsheet when using Rapise 4.0 with MS-Excel 64-bit

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: When you are using the global Rapise Spreadsheet object on a system running the 64-bit version of MS-Office, you may get an error attaching to the spreadsheet. This article describes the cause of the issue and provides a solution and workaround.

h5.a: Testing MS-Word With Rapise

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div:
We had some customers that were looking to record some tests against Microsoft Word 2010. When testing against MS-Word 2010 there are actually two parts to the application:
There is the application ribbon (the menus, navigation, etc.)
There is the MS-Word text window where your content is actually displayed
This article provides some strategies for dealing with both areas.

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: When recording with Chrome, Rapise does not record actions within frames

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.div: When creating web tests with Chrome, objects within cross-frames are not recognized by the Rapise Web Spy and recorder. This article gives a solution.

h5.a: Using Rapise to test websites that contain frames

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: If the website under test contains frames, that presents some challenges to test automation. This article gives tips for success and explains the current limitations.

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: Different XPath Options in Rapise 4.0

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: When testing complex data-driven web applications using Rapise, it is helpful to understand the different ways that Rapise can automatically learn the objects. Rapise can learn an object using either XPATH or CSS. In the case of XPATH there are several strategies that Rapise can use to make the testing more robust. This article describes these strategies and provides some suggestions about which one is the best to use for different scenarios.

h5.a: WebSpy Attribute Filtering

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: The v4.0 release of Rapise adds enhanced attribute filtering to the Web Spy as well as different options for creating XPath queries automatically. This article explains why you would want to use these features and how they can make the testing of complex data-driven web applications much easier.

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: Using Global.DoLoadObjects to Use Rapise Objects from External File

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.p: One of the challenges using an automated testing tool is to organize things in a way that it is logical enough to find something quickly, structured enough to avoid duplication and simple enough to maintain and upgrade.

This statement is also true for Rapise objects. A common requirement is to deal with the same objects within a flow of different test cases. For instance, if an application has “Log In” functionality then many, many tests will require logging-in and logging-out. Each test will have this object in its own object tree. However this causes trouble if a change in the application affects the recognition of the Log In object. All of the test cases will need to be updated. In such situations it is much more convenient to have the “Log In” objects placed into their own file and re-used by other tests.

h5.a: Global.DoWaitFor vs Global.DoWaitForProperty

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.p: The most commonly used synchronization option to make Rapise wait until the application under test (AUT) is ready is the Global.DoSleep action. However having just a sleep may cause an unnecessary delay because we have to consider the maximum wait interval and it may be much less on average. Rapise includes some additional synchronization options for more fine grained control of the test case flow.

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: Using CheckObjectExists(xpathOrObjId) to See if Web Object Exists on Page

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.p: This articles describes how you can use the Navigator.CheckObjectExists(...) action to see if an element exists on a web page and how it differs from the Global.DoWaitFor / DoWaitForProperty actions that are described in another article.

h5.a: What is the purpose of the Tester.EndTest() Function?

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: The Tester.EndTest() function in Rapise is describes as: Marks end of a currently executed test. Calculates test results and performs finalization of test execution. We have found that some of our customers have been confused as what the purpose of this function is.

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: Desktop Application Testing - Choosing the Right Library

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.span: Suppose we have a situation that a thick-client (desktop) application under test (AUT) is based on a technology that is too old or not completely supported by Rapise. Rapise has a number of libraries for different types of apps. Usually Rapise finds the correct libraries using its auto-detection, but sometimes an application is unusual and the auto-detection fails.

h5.a: How to automate the testing of TinyMCE Rich Text Boxes using Rapise

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.span: When you have a rich text box in a web application, the process for recording a test and playing it back will be different to a standard HTML plain text box. When you are using the popular TinyMCE rich text box you have more options to automate it by using its special client-side JavaScript API.

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: Dynamically constructing the .rest file URLs to test REST APIs

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: Sometimes when using Rapise to test REST web services, you want to be able to dynamically change the base URL of the web service yet still use the same URL template and method information. This article describes a process for achieving this.

h5.a: Web testing - Dynamically Switching the Browser in the Same Test

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.p: Sometimes you have a test that you want to run on Chrome, Firefox, and IE in the same script. Normally you write a browser-agnostic test and then have SpiraTest simply call Rapise with different browser names as a parameter and then you have the same test executed multiple times. However suppose you want to have a single test that by itself can run on all the necessary browsers. This article addresses this case.

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: Measuring browser performance with Rapise

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: How do you get the exact time that Rapise takes to load a page? Now, the reports summary shows the overall execution time but if you have pause times between steps then these times are added to the total time of that a page took to display. Customers have asked if Rapise has some kind of function that will allow them to see only the transaction time between pages without the pause times. Does Rapise have something like that? This article provides a solution to these cases.

h5.a: Using Rapise to populate data in an Excel Spreadsheet

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: The built-in Spreadsheet object in Rapise makes it easy to read data from an MS-Excel spreadsheet. What happens if you want to write data back to the Excel sheet?

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: Dynamically changing object locators for Web applications

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: Sometimes you want to dynamically change the XPATH or CSS used in a specific object from within the test script itself. This article explains the process for doing this.

h5.a: Customizing the Rapise Reports

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.p: By default, the reports displayed within Rapise report back each test activity and assert statement as a line in the report with all of the activities and events being displayed in a single flat list regardless of whether they happen inside the main Test() function or a sub-function. This articles explains how you can extend the reporting.

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: Using Rapise 3.1 to test a web page with a multi-select list

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.span: When you have a multi-select list in a web application, you may need to check which items are selected, or to check whether or not a particular item is selected. This article illustrates how to do that.

h5.a: Calling Rapise DoX functions without reporting result

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: When you use a DoX command in Rapise to perform a specific command (e.g. DoDOMChildrenCount() to get a number of object's DOM children), in the report an extra step -- assert -- is created during test execution. Sometimes you want to be able to call a function 'quietly' without it affecting the report.

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: Accessing the Computed Style Properties of an HTML DOM Object

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.div: A common question from our users is, is there a way to get object's style properties that are in effect at a certain point in time. (for example, it could have been inherited from higher level of hierarchy, or modified via JavaScript running on the page)? This article describes how to do this.

h5.a: Certain Hyperlinks won't click during playback with Internet Explorer (IE)

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: Sometimes when you record a test script using IE and then play it back, some of the clicks on hyperlinks will not playback correctly. Rapise will list them as Passed, but the click won't actually be performed.

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: Rapise cannot connect to Firefox immediately after Firefox updates

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.p: If you try and connect to Firefox with Rapise immediately after Firefox has updated, you may see the following error message:

p.font: Microsoft JScript runtime error: 'Navigator.GetBrowserHWND()' is null or not an object

h5.a: Fixing 'Unable to cast object of type 'System.DBNull' to type 'System.String'' errors in Spira v4.x

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: Sometimes when you are saving Rapise test scripts into some early versions of Spira v4.2.x.x (e.g. Spira v4.2.0.1 - v4.2.0.5) you can start getting these errors on the Test Case details page. You may also get the error for other reasons in earlier versions of Spira v4.x.

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: Accessing the Spira v4.2 REST API to get test cases in a release

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: This article describes the process and provides an example for accessing the Spira v4.2 REST API to get a filtered list of test cases in a release.

h5.a: How to Use Sub-Tests and Common Objects with REST Web Service Tests

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: It is often useful to have a common set of code libraries and objects that can be reused amongst multiple tests. With Rapise this can be done by creating a common test and then including it into the other actual tests. However due to the way REST web service tests are stored, there are some slight changes needed to handle REST services. This articles describes the process.

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: Rapise Won't Record Steps or Display Reports

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: If you are running Rapise and you suddenly start to find that none of your recordings get saved and the reports are not displaying during execution it may be due to the fact that you have saved your Rapise test folder onto a Network Share.

h5.a: Scripts created with Rapise 2.1 or earlier no longer playing back correctly in Rapise 2.2 or later

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

span.style: color: rgb(102, 0, 204); font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 13.3333330154419px; line-height: 16px;

div.span: In Rapise 2.2, "DoClick" behavior was changed, so we don't do a click but rather just position the mouse over the control and do API-level "click" event. However we provided a way to enable backward compatibility.

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: Testing Silverlight Applications

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: When testing Silverlight applications, you may find that Rapise fails to recognize the objects in the Silverlight app using the UIAutomation library. When using the Rapise Spy Tool, the whole app is identified as a single window. The objects such as a dropdown, buttons etc. inside the silverlight app are not individually recognized.

h5.a: Disabling the generation of comments during Recording

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: By default Rapise records user actions with a line commented out for each action. This articles describes how you can disable this behavior if you just want the script lines recorded on their own.

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: My Actions are Not Recorded

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div:
By design Rapise tries to record user activity on the highest possible level. This makes recorded actions more readable and universal (often several lower-level user actions are combined)
Rapise uses a heuristics to distinguish meaningful activity from low level actions. In some cases this leads to a result that some user activity is not automatically recorded (for example, a mouse click before entering text in a box). There is a broad range of available UI platforms and libraries. The variety of graphical widgets makes user interface robust and beautiful. Rapise tries to recognize as much objects as possible. However this range is growing and there are always widgets that are not being recorded.

h5.a: Anti-Virus Software and Test Automation

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.p: Anti-virus software is very sensitive to test automation tools. This is normal, because test automation tools usually do API, keyboard and mouse hooking to be able to record and playback user actions.

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: How are Global Functions stored and recalled?

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: We need to call many common functions from a common library frequently.

h5.a: Why is My Flex application recorded as mouse clicks?

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.span: A Flex application requires some instrumentation to be ready for testing. By default Flash player has security restrictions preventing Rapise from accessing the application contents. Please, check the this help topic to learn more about Adobe Flex testing.

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: The Recorder asks for a Library. Which should I choose?

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

p.span: In most cases "Auto" is the best choice. Manual selection of libraries may be needed in more advanced scenarios and is intended for experienced users.

h5.a: Does Rapise work with Windows UAC?

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: If you are using Rapise on Windows Vista or Windows 7 it is not necessary to disable the Windows User Account Control (UAC) to use Rapise. Unlike some other automated testing tools on market, you can use Rapise with UAC enabled.

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: Executing Under a VM or Remote Desktop

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.p: Sometimes you need to test an application running on a VM or remote computer using Remote Desktop (RDP) rather than a physical terminal. This guide explains how to ensure that Rapise is able to correctly fire events on the application under test.

h5.a: Waiting Until Application Ready

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.p: Sometimes you need to synchronize the test script so that it waits for a specific application event (change for status message or wait for some specific value). This guide explains how to ensure that Rapise waits for the appropriate condition.

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: Reading an Object's State

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: Sometimes it is necessary to examine the state of an object. For example, determine if Toggle Button is pressed or not, Radio/Check Button is checked or not, etc. This guide describes a couple of different ways of achieving this.

h5.a: About Highlighting (Flash Command) Rectangles

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: Rapise has a choice of visual effects it can use when highlighting a control being learned during the recording process. This guide describes the different modes.

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: Choosing Object Type Manually

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: Sometimes Rapise will incorrectly recognize a GUI component. This guide outlines how you can manually change the object type captured during recording.

h5.a: Capture Screenshots During Playback

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.p: When playing back a test it is useful to be able to capture the screen as its current state so that the cause of any test failures can be more easily deduced.

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: Working with Right-Click Context Menus

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: The context menu control is not natively supported by Rapise, but one can use a simple workaround.

h5.a: Working with Selectable Lists

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: The behavior of list and combobox controls in GUI applications sometimes require additional attention. This guide explains the different types of combobox controls and best practices for testing them in Rapise.

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: Recording Web Menus

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: Many web sites have dynamic site menus. This guide outlines the best practices for recording events associated with such dynamic site menus.

h5.a: My Actions are Not Recorded

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.p: By design Rapise tries to record user activity on the highest possible level. This makes recorded actions more readable and universal. However that sometimes means that certain actions that a user performs won't be automatically picked up. This guide explains ways to handle situations when a specific user activity is not recorded.

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: Recording Mouse Activity

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: This guide describes the different types of mouse events and how they are recorded in Rapise.

h5.a: Re-Using Test Logic

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: It is common for test scenarios to share similar pieces of functionality. A good example of such sharing is login logic. This guide outlines ways in which you can share such logic to avoid having repeated code in your tests.

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: Working with HTML XPath

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: When testing web applications you will often need to use XPath to query the browser DOM for elements based on the scenario under test. This guide explains how you can use XPath queries with Rapise to make your browser testing more flexible and adaptive to changes on the screen.

h5.a: Working with HTML Tables containing Dynamic Data

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: Many web sites use HTML tables to display lists of tabular data. When testing such applications you will often need to dynamically search for items in the table to verify that the application under test performed correctly. This guide outlines best practices for accessing data held in HTML tables.

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: Change Object Value or Text

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: This guide describes the different ways that you can change the value of text label of an object.

h5.a: Analog Recording

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: Sometimes the application under test doesn't contain any learnable objects. In that case you may need to use the fallback of Analog Recording. This guide describes how you perform analog recording.

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: Simulated Objects

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: This guide describes what simulated objects are and when they should be used.

h5.a: Passing Test Parameters

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.p: There are many different ways of passing test parameters to Rapise from an external system. This guide describes the different ways of passing parameter values to Rapise.

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: Creating a Set of Tests to Run in Rapise

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: This guide describes how you manage groups of Rapise tests together in situations where you are not using SpiraTest test sets.

h5.a: Using Dynamic Linked Library (DLLs) in Test Scripts

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: Sometimes you need to call code libraries from your Rapise tests, for example when the built-in JavaScript scripting engine does not provide the necessary functionality. This guide explains how to call an external DLL from your Rapise test script.

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: How does Rapise detect if a dialog is already open?

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: There are several ways to find if something is already on the screen, this article explains some of the options.

h5.a: Analog Testing when the Machine does not have the Break Key

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: When using Rapise for analog testing you need to use the key sequence CTRL+BREAK to start and stop the analog recorder. However some machines (particularly smaller laptops) do not have a BREAK or PAUSE (often the same function as BREAK) key. This article describes some solutiomns

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: Using DoDOMChildrenCount and DoDOMQueryXPath to inspect child HTML elements

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: Often you want to be able to query for the child elements on a web page that are dynamically created and therefore not good candidates for LEARNing individually. This article explains how you can use the dynamic XPATH methods of Rapise to accomplish this task.

h5.a: After installing Windows Update KB3025390 Rapise No Longer Connects to IE

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: An old (December 9th, 2014) security update for Microsoft Windows and Internet Explorer (KB3025390) broke the support in IE for 'out-of-process' code execution. This effectively prevented an automated testing application such as Rapise from automating Internet Explorer (IE) applications. This was subsequently fixed by Microsoft on February 10th, 2015 with the KB 3021952 update.

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: How to Get Rapise Trace Logging Information

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: When using Rapise, it is often useful to see how Rapise is identifying objects in the Application Under Test (AUT) and if necessary find out why Rapise is not able to locate a specific object. This article outlines how to increase the logging level in Rapise.

h5.a: Automating HTML File Upload Boxes

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.p: Sometimes you have to automate the uploading of files using an HTML file upload control. This article explains how to record and playback such a script.

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: Code Completion of Native JavaScript Objects

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: Rapise has built-in code completion logic that lets it suggest the available list of functions for a specific object. However since JavaScript is fundamentally an un-typed language, for the code completion to work, there are some tips and tricks that you can use.

h5.a: Recording Popup JavaScript Confirmation Boxes

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.p: When you are recording a test against a Web application you may have to deal with a popup JavaScript confirm or alert box. This article describes the process for dealing with them.

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: How to automate the testing of Rich Text Boxes using Rapise

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: When you have a rich text box in a web application, the process for recording a test and playing it back will be different to a standard HTML plain text box. This is because the browser actually uses a separate IFRAME and HTML document for the editable rich text box. This article explains the process for recording/playing back such a test.

h5.a: Adding Support for Custom Flex Controls

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: By default the Rapise Flex library supports a wide variety of Flex controls which will be capable of testing the majority of application. However sometimes there will be an unknown objects which will be learnt as a generic object with FlexObject flavor. The article describes support for such custom Flex controls:

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: Using Rapise to Validate Display of Data Grid Data

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.p: One common requirement is to run a query in an application being tested and verify that the data on the screen matches the data in the application. This article explains the recommended process for doing this.

h5.a: Choosing the Web Browser in Rapise from SpiraTest / SpiraTeam

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.p: When writing a web test in Rapise you will often want to run the same test script in all three web browsers (IE, Firefox and Chrome). You will want to be able to choose the Test Script from within Rapise when debugging the test and then from a Test Set in SpiraTest when you move the test into production. This article explains the process.

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: Sending Special Keys to the Current Application

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.p: You can use the Global.DoSendKeys('...'); command in Rapise to send keypresses to the current application. Sometimes you will want to send special control keys to the application (e.g. Page Down, or CTRL + Key). This article explains the way to do this.

h5.a: Turning off Chome and Firefox Auto-Updating

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: When you are testing a web application against different environments, it can be useful disable to default browser auto-updating policies so that you have a stable testing environment. This articles describes how to disable the auto-updating policies of Google Chrome and Firefox.

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: A DLL required for this install to complete could not be run

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.p: If you run one of our installation packages (.msi) and receive the following message:

p.font: A DLL required for this install to complete could not be run

h5.a: Enabling Windows Installer (.msi) Trace Logging

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: Sometimes when installing our products you get error messages during the installation and it's necessary to provide Inflectra support personnel with detailed trace/logging information so that they can better support you. This article describes the steps necessary to enable Windows Installer (.msi) trace logging.

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: How to resolve WScript.CreateObject: Could not connect object errors

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.p: Sometimes when you install Rapise on a computer that had a previous version of Rapise installed, when you try to record and/or playback a test you get the following error message:

p.font: C:\Program Files (x86)\Inflectra\Rapise\Engine\Player.js WScript.CreateObject: Could not connect object.

div.p: This article describes the steps to correct the error.

h5.a: Accessing Clipboard in Rapise

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.p: Sometimes when automating a test, you need to access the local Windows clipboard. This article describes how to access the Windows clipboard programmatically.

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: Testing Win32 applications to verify that controls change display state

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.p:
Sometimes you may have a button (or other control) that can have a different appearance depending on the different focus statuses.
For example, the default status without focus is a grey image, whereas when the mouse hovering over it becomes blue. Then when the mouse left button is held down on the button (and not released), the image changes to a red image.
Finally, when the button is activated using the tab key to tab into the button and the mouse is somewhere else, it has a fourth color.
This article discusses solutions for how to test these kinds of situation

h5.a: Using Navigator.ExecJS to execute JavaScript code inside a browser

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.p: Sometimes you need to execute JavaScript code at a browser side and get the result. You can do this with Navigator.ExecJS.

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: Getting the State of a Win32 object using Rapise

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: Sometimes you need to be able to test the state of a specific Win32 object in Rapise to see if it is enabled, disabled, is activated, etc. This sample illustrates how to get the numeric and textual value of the object's state.

h5.a: Accessing Files and I/O functions using Rapise

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.p: Sometimes using Rapise you need to access files on the Windows filesystem, either for testing purposes, or to object test data stored in a flat CSV, TSV or text file. This sample illustrates how you can access the File System using Rapise and the Windows FileSystemObject (http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/aa242706(v=vs.60).aspx).

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: Using Simulated Objects

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.p: Simulated objects are found by looking at the parameters of the object (x number of pixels from the top of the window, y number of pixels from the left of the window, etc). One common question that has arisen is - during playback, does Rapise take into account screen resolution? If the resolution on the computer you run it on is different from the one it records on the location of the object will change relative to the number of pixels. So on the computer you record it on the top parameter might be 200 but on a different resolution it might be 180. Would Rapise recognize that the resolution is different and adjust for that?

h5.a: Javascript .js not associated with Windows Scripting Host

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.p: Sometimes if you have installed a program that associates itself with the .js file extension, you will see the following error when you try and record/play a Rapise test:
div.div: Microsoft (R) Windows Script Host Version 5.8
Copyright (C) Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.
Input Error: There is no script engine for file extension ".js".

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: Accessing Child Objects in a Java AWT/Swing application

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: This article describes how to access child objects of a Learned Java AWT/Swing object when using the Rapise Java library. Sometimes when you Learn a top-level object, you want to be able to programmatically query the object to locate the child objects that are visible in the Java SPY.

h5.a: Accessing child components of a WPF / Silverlight ListBox

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

p.span: When you have a WPF or Silverlight application that has a list box (or other control that supports templates such as a Tree) that has an item template that contains sub-controls, you may need to access the individual controls rather than just the entire list item. This article outlines the approach for doing this.

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: Dynamically changing object locators for WPF/Silverlight applications

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

font.p: Sometimes you will have controls in a WPF or Silverlight application which use dynamic lists.
Depending on certain settings, the widgets in the list will appear in different places.
This means that a Learned Rapise object which works fine if its in the original ListBox[0] location position is then played-back when it's displayed in another position, it will be ListBox[1] or [2].
Unlike the XPath option with web testing, Rapise doesn't currently allow regular expressions (Regex) in locators stored inside the objects.js file. This article describes a way around the problem:

h5.a: Executing a process and checking if it's still running

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.p: If you use the Global.DoLaunch(...) command to launch a Windows console application, it will return a process ID. This article provides some sample code for executing a console application and checking to make sure that the process is not still running.

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: Executing JavaScript commands against Web Browser

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.p: Sometimes you want to be able to open a browser window and execute JavaScript commands directly against the DOM objects rather than using the Rapise learned objects. This article explains the recommended way of doing this.

h5.a: Extending RapiseLauncher inactivity timeout

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: When executing Rapise scripts from SpiraTest using RapiseLauncher there is a 10-minute inactivity timeout. If your scripts have periods of inactivity that last longer than 10 minutes, you may need to extend the default timeout. This article describes the steps for doing this.

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: Executing SQL Database Queries from Rapise

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.p: Sometimes when you are running Rapise tests you need to run direct database queries to prepare the data in the test application, or you need to make queries against the database to verify that some user interactions left the data in a specific state.
The sample script below illustrates how you can call database queries directly from the Rapise scripting editor:

h5.a: Selecting Browser for Test

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: This article describes how to playback a test in a different browser from the one it was recorded in.

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: Unable to record/play a Java applet using Rapise inside a web browser

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: Sometimes you have the situation where you can record/play a Java application using Rapise having correctly installed the Java bridge and set the JAVA_HOME environment variable correctly, but applets running inside a web browser do not work. This article provides some suggested solutions

h5.a: Detecting the presence of an object in Rapise

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: Often you need to be able to check for the presence of an object and then depending on whether the object is visible perform one of two possible sets of operations. This article explains the recommended way of doing this in Rapise 1.5.

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: Using Rapise to extract test data from an Excelsheet

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.p: Often you want to be able to parameterize your Rapise tests to have a common set of test functions that can use different combinations of test data. You can use a MS-Excel spreadsheet to store the test data and use Rapise to read out the matching values. This articles provides a sample for doing this.

h5.a: Passing Parameters to a Rapise script through the command line

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.p: This article describes the syntax for passing parameters from the Windows 32-bit command-line to a Rapise script. Note that you need to make sure that you're using the 32-bit command line on a 64-bit machine. I.e. follow the instructions in this KB article - https://www.inflectra.com/Support/KnowledgeBase/KB17.aspx

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: Using Global.DoInvokeTest() to pass parameters between tests

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.p: Sometimes you want a test script to be able to call another sub-test as part of its operation. You can do this using the Global.DoInvokeTest('path to test', [parameters]); function. This articles provides a more detailed example for doing this.
The high-level information can be found on our website at: https://www.inflectra.com/Rapise/Guides.aspx?feature=Passing-Test-Parameters

h5.a: How to handle Windows/Objects that have names that change

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word

div.div: When using Rapise to record test scripts against Windows, Java, Flex, or other thick client applications that have windows or objects whose names may change in between test runs, you will usually need to make changes to either the test script or the learned objects so that they can match correctly. This article outlines some suggested techniques for recording/playing back scripts against such applications.

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: How Do I Ensure No Other Browser Windows Open

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.p: When running a test you will often want to make sure there are no other browser windows open. This is commonly done either at the start or end of the test. This article describes how you do this.

h5.a: How to successfully include and use common functions and objects

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.p: It is often useful to have a common set of code libraries and objects that can be reused amongst multiple tests. With Rapise this can be done by creating a common test and then including it into the other actual tests. This article describes the process

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: Running a Rapise script from the command-line on a 64-bit machine

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.p: If you try and run a Rapise script from the command-line on a 64-bit machine you may get an error message. Learn how to fix it from the article.

h5.a: Test-Scripts suddenly moving/clicking at false locations

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.p: If you have your browser zoom set to a value that is not 100% when recording or playing back scripts it will affect the playback reliability. Specifically Rapise will click/move at/to false locations in the test browser.You need to set your browser zoom to 100% before doing any playback/recording activities.

div.class: clearfix visible-md visible-lg

h5.a: How do I change the URL of the website being tested in Rapise.

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.p: We are in the process of adding a new testing server that we would like to be able to run automation scripts against.
I just wanted to see if there is a process documented for converting scripts and objects to point to a different web address?

h5.a: Recording Infragistics Applications with Rapise Throws Error

div.class: is-unformatted font90 children-font90 pale mt2 mb3 sm-mb4 break-word
div.p: If you try and record a test script in Rapise using just the 'Infragistics' library you will get the following error message:

p.font: C:\Program Files (x86)\Inflectra\Rapise\Engine\Recorder.js(285, 3) Microsoft JScript runtime error: 'ManagedObjectSelectableBehavior_OnMouseEvent' is undefined
